PICKERING: And what are you up to, young lady?
PICKERING: BECKY-LEE: You seem awfully bright this morning, grandpappy. Things with the videotape go well?
PICKERING: Better than well, Becky-Lee. Just about perfect, in fact. But you'll just have to wait a while before you find out how well, so no more interrogations.
PICKERING: BECKY-LEE: Oh, I can handle suspense. Tell me something, though. Have you noticed any new arrivals in town over the last couple of days? Apart from me and Charley. In particular, any Brits?
PICKERING: You know, I can help you there. A guy by the name of Leatherbridge, Lethbridge Stewart, that's it. Lethbridge Stewart from England. Part of the secession party. Real nice guy. Could be he's your man. Most likely you'll find him at the Friendly Inn Motel on Tennyson Boulevard.
PICKERING: BECKY-LEE: Well, wow. Thanks, grandpappy. I'll head over there. High time I got into evil combating mode. Bye now.
PICKERING: Bye now, Becky-Lee.
MARCHOSIAS: Now to taste the delights of you, my flesh.
DOCTOR: I am the Doctor. I am the Doctor.
CRANE: And what is the Doctor? Can you tell me that? A bicardial biped of Gallifrey, a spatio-temporal rolling stone who's had more faces than a dog has had fleas. A wide-eyed idealist who renounced his Time Lord heritage centuries ago about some misplaced revolutionary fervour, and has never since had the maturity to
DOCTOR: How do you know that, Gideon? I've never told that to anybody.
CRANE: Charley, Sam, Ace, Evelyn, Nyssa, Romana, Sarah Jane, Jamie, Polly, lan, Barbara and Susan, Dear, dear Susan.
DOCTOR: How? How do you know all this?
CRANE: I know everything there is to know about these matters. Haven't you worked it out yet? You aren't the Doctor, my poor mad confused friend. No, I am.

elements.text: PART THREE
You're the Doctor? Don't be ridiculous. You're Gideon Crane. I heard you tell them.

I can understand your perplexity, old man, so don't worry. How do you think I felt when I woke up the other morning and found the chap in the compartment next to me was announcing to all and sundry that he was me!
Why didn't you protest before? Why that business in the laboratory?

What do you think? I want out of this place, this asylum. I was hardly going to tell the authorities to ignore what you were saying because I was really the Time Lord from outer space. No, I engaged my brain before activating my voice. I came up with a nom-de-plume, Gideon Crane of the London Torch, and a cover story that I was here to follow this state's emergence as the USA's fifty first. Then once I'd convinced them I was sane, I knew they'd let me go. So, if you're me, if you're the Doctor, you explain why you didn't do that, eh?
Oh no, no, no, no, no. Surely it's your job to convince me why, if I'm not the Doctor, I think I am.
That's easy, old man. You're insane.
Oh. Gosh, who's that?
Knocking on door.
Hello? I'm just going to sleep.
Door broken down. Marchosias roars.
Senator Pickering! That's an unusual way of entering a lady's boudoir!
Ha! (sings, sort of) Charley is my darling, my darling, my darling. Hold still, little girl. I won't take long to kill you.
Charming!
No more than an hour or two. Honest.
You're not Becky-Lee's grandfather, I take it.
You think? Hmm, let's see. I smash doors down, I enter young lady's bedrooms, I want to kill you. Nope, I guess I'm not him.
Charley throws something, which breaks.
Hey, that was a gift from Becky-Lee's mom. Used to keep good time, too.
You, you beast!
Yep. Oh, and if I can do that to a door, I don't think a chair is really going to slow me down, do you?
It's not for you.
Crash of glass! Charley cries out.
Why, you
Young varmint. Now just come back here, now, you hear me?
Sounds of the outside.
I wonder how far I could jump and chase her before this body's heart went bang? No, better not risk it.
Typing on keyboard.
Message timed twelve fourteen EST. Nothing to report since this AM. Will shortly attempt to gain readmittance to
Knock on door.
Hang on.
Unlocks door and opens it.
Hello. May I help you?
BECKY-LEE: Hiya. I'm not selling anything.
Of course not.
BECKY-LEE: I'm here on behalf of Charley Pollard?
Never heard of him. Awfully sorry, I don't follow much American TV or pop music.
BECKY-LEE: It is Doctor Lethbridge Stewart, isn't it?
I'm not a doctor, no.
BECKY-LEE: Oh. Seen any demons recently?
I think perhaps you should come in, young lady. Miss er?
BECKY-LEE: Just call me Becky-Lee.
Door closes.
Breathless.

All right. Right. Charley, that's not Waldo Pickering. I'd better warn Becky-Lee. But where is she now? And how far am I going to get in this nightdress and no slippers. Ow! Of course, the Tardis. If I can find the Tardis. I remember it landing. Oh, where? Where? It was dark, and there was a face on the scanner, and I woke up in that awful room with Becky-Lee and those other poor girls. Ow! Maybe I should try and find that. See if I can jog my memory and retrace my steps.
Motorbike engine.
Are you sure you know how to drive this machine?
BECKY-LEE: Sure I do.
Er, the alley's just around here.
BECKY-LEE: This one?
Yes.
Engine stops.
Oh. I must get one of these for Doris.
BECKY-LEE: Can't see any demons now. Wait here.
All right.
Footsteps.
Are you sure you're all right?
BECKY-LEE [OC]: Been fighting demons for years. Perfectly safe. Oh.
Hold on, I'm coming. I'm, I'm
BECKY-LEE: No, no, I'm fine. That's very odd. You know, there's a big blue
What I don't understand is how you got involved.
BECKY-LEE: Me and Charley got picked up and taken to the Hellfire Club, where some mad woman called Pargeter said we were to become the Pretty Little Satin Bottoms
Pargeter? What, Doctor Pargeter? Why do all roads lead to the Dashwood Institute, I wonder.
BECKY-LEE: Never mind me, what about you? You said something about the United Nations, yeah?

Yes, got brought in undercover to explore the Dashwood Institute. When we brought our version of their PSI machine online, there was an almighty ruckus from the government's Doomwatch thinktanks. They claimed it could be used to bring in eugenics by
the back door. That a man's psychic matrix could be transferred to an electronic memory. BECKY-LEE: I see. No, I don't. What's the problem?
Well, when they return the memories to the host, they could have edited them, taken away the elements that make them undesirable. Designer brains, that's the buzz word they're using in Whitehall.
BECKY-LEE: So you got sent over here to scout around.
And although I can't prove it, that Institute has something more going on than just the PSI experiments on some unfortunate patients. I just can't prove anything, and now I. Hello, are you listening?
BECKY-LEE: Mister Lethbridge Stewart, look here. There're sulphur deposits and scorch marks on the side of the alley. You were right. Genuine manifestations. No projections or illusions here.
Urgh. Well, thank you for endorsing what I saw. So nice to be believed. BECKY-LEE: But if you're not Charley's friend, I wonder who is?
Charley's friend? Well, who might that be?
BECKY-LEE: Someone she came here with. A Brit. She calls him a doctor.
Doctor? But, no. No, that's too much of a coincidence.
BECKY-LEE: What is?
I knew a man who called himself the Doctor. If he were here, he could help us. Where's this Charley from?
BECKY-LEE: Somewhere between England and Mars, I think. She might be a bit mad. She didn't know what television was.
Perfect. Sounds like the Doctor's type.
BECKY-LEE: You mean, when she said she was from 1930 she meant it?
Probably. Right, come on then.
BECKY-LEE: And just where are we going now?

The Institute, of course. There was a man there, posing as a journalist. Gideon Crane, he said his name was. I should have realised it. He tried to tell me he was the Doctor. Said he knew me. And those demons that chased me and that other fellow. Oh, just the sort of thing the Doctor would be mixed up with.
BECKY-LEE: So, the Institute, yeah?
One other thing though, Miss Kowalczck.
BECKY-LEE: What's that?
I'll drive your motorised beast this time.
BECKY-LEE: Hey!
The way I see it is this. Anem. Now, tell me, Doctor, if you still insist on my name.
Yes, I most certainly do.
As you wish. Now, do you remember arriving in America at all?
Yes.
How?
By er, T. All right, no.

You and Charley have just left Venice. Lovely big party, got a bit wet on the canals, yes? And when we got back to the Tardis I er, sorry, you decided it was time to see an old friend here in the States. Grace, yes?
Grace?
So, after setting the coordinates we, sorry, you and Charley decided there was one
other thing to do first.
So I said to Lincoln, Abe, I said, don't go to the theatre. I couldn't have been clearer.
Operating the console. Ramsey the Vortisaur is squawking a bit.
I've seen Our American Cousin, I told him. Not a laugh in it.
Doctor.
The only good thing in it is that Booth fellow, but he's not performing tonight. Did he listen? Do they ever listen?
Doctor.
None of them listen, and I imagine you've not been listening either, have you?
Ramsey's sad.
I'm sorry, Charley, but I just don't think it's fair any more.
Oh, but Doctor, he's so sweet.

Charley, he's not been well. That has, I suspect, been curbing his more antisocial tendencies. Living in the Tardis environs has probably kept him effectively fed and watered long enough. We're in the vortex. We can let him go now. He needs to be back amongst the other Vortisaurs.
Oh, he loves us, don't you, boy?
Charley. Charley, Charley, what am I to do with you? Vortisaurs are dangerous carnivores. They feed off time. Remember what happened to that man's arm on the R101?
He was going to die anyway.
Yes.
Oh, I'm sorry, Doctor. Really I am. I didn't mean that. But Ramsey's just a baby. He's tame.
I doubt that, Charley. He's, he's just been sick but now he's fine. And no, Ramsey, your charm doesn't work on me.
The Tardis stops.
Here we are, the epicentre of the vortex, where he first hitched a lift and
Squawk! Flapping of wings.
Er, Charley, very slowly back away.
He won't hurt me, will you, boy.
Charley, get down.
Ramsey flies around, occasionally diving.
Doctor, what's he doing?
True colours, Charley, true colours.
But I looked after him. Why's he going for me?
Food.
What? I'm not food!

Oh yes you are, Charley, to Ramsey. He can sense the time distortion around you. The fabric of the Web of Time splintering all over you. I don't understand it either but hold on, I'm going to try ejecting him.
How?
Come on, Ramsey. Leave Charley. Nice Time Lord. Here, yum yums. Remember my blood? Remember how you liked the taste of that? Come to me.
Doctor, don't get too close to the doors.
Now, Charley. Open the doors now.
But you
Now!
The doors open.
It's working, Charley. Charley, he's being drawn out, back into the very heart of the vortex.
So are you!
He's feeding off the time energy inside and outside.
Sounds like rushing wind.
(distorted) Con, con, concentrate, Charley. Close the doors.
(distorted) I'm, I'm trying. I'm trying.
Oh, no! Try an emergency materialisation. Bounce us straight out of the centre of the time distortion.
Is that safe?
Absolutely not. Normally I'd forbid such a rash of action, but needs.
I can't reach it. Everything's sparking out.
Hit everything at once, now!
Mad flurry of console controls then just the engines. The voice distortions have stopped.
Where are we going?
I don't know. Oh, my head. My head hurts.
Oh, Doctor. On the scanner. There's a man
The Tardis will avoid him. I hope. Argh!
The Tardis materialises.
My head. Must get fresh air. Must get out.
And the next thing I knew, that we both knew, was that we were waking up in here, in this, this loony bin. Like to hazard a guess what happened next?
Amaze me.
Well, my surmise is that whatever the time distortion broke in the Tardis affected the symbiotic nuclei. You do know what a symbiotic nucleus is, I suppose?
I think so.

The means by which the Tardis controls are inextricably bound to the psychic profile of the particular Time Lord assigned to the particular Tardis. Or in my, our, case, not so much assigned as, well, utilised, anyway. Permanently locked in the Doctor's mind, old man. So, if that went seriously wrong, the Doctor's mind could so easily be scrambled by the experience.
That doesn't explain why we both remember being the Doctor.

Ah, well, the Tardis crash-landed in this town down a rather dodgy back alley where one who shall now be referred to as Zebadiah Doe was answering a call of nature or some such. Admiring the night sky and the bright moonshine. The temporal field, disrupted by Ramsey's frenzied attack, was spilling out from everywhere, and the already raw and damaged nuclei created a link between the two people rather than the Doctor and his ship. A vast swathe of the Doctor's memories and thought patterns would have flooded into the other's mind, wiping out what was already there and turning him into a copy of the Doctor. You're just a facsimile, if a fairly good one, of me, I'm afraid. Some of my most recent memories, yes, but little of my deeper past.
It was you. You were the face on the scanner.
No, how many more times. You were.
Rubbish.
Let's put this to the test, then, all right? Twenty questions. Number one.

We only need to get a few more thousand tonight. I'll be Governor within the week and. No, I have put a plan into motion already. No, Waldo Pickering is no longer any threat. Malabogia's succession is now a certainty.
Knock on door.
Look, Bobby Joe. You concentrate on getting tonight's telethon looking like a class one programme, I'll concentrate on the detail here. I will.
Knocking.
Look, I gotta go. Talk to you later.
Telephone is put down.
Come in.
Door opens.
Brigham.
Door closes.
Success. Those catatonic patients you wanted? Arriving this afternoon. Transferred down from one of the clubs in
Churches, Dale. From today on they are churches. At least as far as the balance sheets go.
All right, there's no need to get precious. Churches it is, Brigham. Anyway, they'll be here by dinnertime tonight.
You don't need me there, do you? Only tonight's the big night on TV.
Strangely enough, Brigham, I have been planning this for a long time.
I'm sorry, Dale. Of course you have.
Zebadiah goes back on the PSI. I copy his matrix into the memory by stages, and each time transfer the stage into a catatonic patient before wiping the memory and going on to the next stage.
If this man really has the mental capacity we think, it'll be far more managable spread amongst a dozen others.
One question. If Marchosias is using Pickering's body, do you want me to wipe the Senator's stored brainprints?

Hell, no, Dale. Insufferable idiot he may be, but Waldo is, ha, was, of great political pedigree, and quite shrewd. Transfer it onto a couple of megagig quantum CD roms. I intend to make use of his experience over the next few decades. Dale, please don't forget that my love for you surpasses all of this. You do know that, don't you?
Yes. Yes, I do. Oh, Brigham, when was the last time we shared a meal? Just us. When was the last time we took a weekend away?
You're right, Dale. I've been uncaring and too wrapped up in all this. Once tonight is out of the way, I promise we'll make time.
I'll go and prepare Zebadiah Doe for transfer.
And I'll see you later after the broadcast.
Door opens and closes.
Okay, you can crawl out of the shadows now, Marchosias. I know you're there.
Marchosias is heavily sarcastic throughout.
Fascinating, Mister Dashwood. I had no idea you and Doctor Pargeter were
so allied. Why keep it so secret?
It would hardly befit my television persona as a man of the Lord to be seen cavorting with the hired help, now would it?
A man of the Lord? Oh yes, I saw your mail order diploma hanging on the walls of Hell. How many milk carton proofs of purchase did you have to send off?

I will not endure this for much longer, Marchosias. In case you've forgotten, by the incantations of the Hellfire Club, Lucifer has provided you to do my bidding, not give me smart ass backchat. Now, I need to be in an absolutely serene state of mind to deliver tonight's evangelical message to the masses. Did you want anything?
Oh, nothing. In fact, I think I have everything I need right now. Thank you, O master. If I may skidaddle?
Go, and remember your job this afternoon. The local TV reporters will be here in an hour.
You're such a superb schemer, O master. Even Lucifer himself bows down before your skill.
Electronic noise as it leaves.
Dale, Marchosias, Zebadiah Doe. Why must I ally myself with (sigh) with such tawdriness.
Motorbike engine.
BECKY-LEE: Whoa.
This modern Hellfire Club on Twenty Sixth Street. Presumably they're responsible.

BECKY-LEE: Not from what I saw. None of that lot could conjure up a box of Snickers. You need a master magician to channel the energy from the chants and sacrifices. I just thought. Some clubs in Europe have got round this by using electronic channelling techniques. Digital demonology, the wave of the future.
Using electronics that control psychic emanations.
BECKY-LEE: No one wants good old honest craftsmanship these days.
Now, what was I saying about all roads leading to Brigham Elisha Dashwood?
Hello? Anybody there? One empty Hellfire Club. Time for a bit of a nose around, Miss Pollard. See what we can
Can I help you?
Oh! Oh my, you gave me such a start, creeping around like that. It's not right.
Whereas breaking and entering a private dwelling is okay, yes?
Breaking and? I'll have you know I did no such thing. The door was wide open. Look.
Of course it was. I was escorting a new batch of young ladies to their (pause) gainful employment.
Oh.
Have we met before?
Ye, er, no! No, I don't think so.
Oh well, we have now. Come with me. Dressed in nothing but a nightdress. You must be freezing.
Nightdress? Oh, oh yes, silly me. Tell you what, I'll just go home and change, and then come back and ow! Let me go, you brute! Oh, Senator. Oh, no. No, it's you again, isn't it.
Hello, beautiful. Oh, sorry to burst in unannounced, Doctor Pargeter.
Pleased to see you, Marchosias. Can you help bring this wayward girl upstairs to join the other Pretty Little Satin Bottoms?
Oh, botheration.
Now, the Doctor and Turlough encounter lupine activity in which South American country?
Lupine, werewolves, er. No, no, no, I don't
Rio. Next. When Victoria Waterfield left the Tardis, what was the name of the family she moved in with?
Victoria. Er, ah, don't tell me.
The Harrises. Whose Limitation Effect precludes multiple temporal re-entries.
Blinovitch.
Oh, very well done. One out of twenty. Go to the top of the class. Of course, things wouldn't be so bad if they hadn't used that machine on you.
The PSI895?

You see, the Time Lord thought patterns you'd absorbed when our minds melded, well, the poor circuitry of the PSI machine simply wasn't designed to cope with it. And I was standing nearby, so I copped a blast of hopelessly distorted brainwaves and ended up back here. Oh, never mind. I'll soon convince them I'm fit to walk amongst the compos mentis again. It's you I'm worrying about, friend Zebadiah.
Really? Why's that?
What must all these revelations be doing to you? You're already confused enough about your identity.

Maybe you're right. I don't admit to anything, of course, but let's suppose you are. That would mean that the PSI recorded the mangled matrices of both of us from my brain. Before it blew a fuse, I mean. Somewhere on a quantum CD ROM that brain pattern might still exist. If I could superimpose it upon the matrix my brain already contains

The part of the recorded matrix which is the real you would boost the original residue you retain and bingo! You'd be back in your original personality with no delusions about being the Doctor. Very good. I was wondering if you'd see it eventually.
That minuet is playing again.

So close to ascendence. So close to becoming Governor, and then one step to the White House. Marchosias ridiculing me. Dale Pargeter like a love-sick puppy dog rapidly outliving her usefullness for the campaign. (sings) Dashwood for the White House let the anthem ring, Dashwood for the White House let the children sing.
Telephone rings.

Yes? Oh, Dale, hi honey. Oh, excellent. Patch them through to my CCTV monitor, will you? Okay, it's on and oh my. Dale, excellent! A lovely new batch of girls for tonight and stop. That one, beside you. Yes, her. Barefoot, flimsy little nightdress. Bring her closer to the camera. Dale, listen to me. Have her segregated from the rest. Never mind why. All right, look, I've seen her before. She's one of the ones who must have escaped last night. Yes, yes. So have her bathed and scented and dressed in costume number, ah yes, number seventeen. With real jewellery.
Dress seventeen, Queen of Hell special. Your beloved Brigham's planning to get married.
What?
Married? Me?
He can't marry her.
Why not? I would. She's gorgeous.
Because, because.
Oh. Right. Because you love him and think he'll marry you. Of course. Silly of me. I shouldn't have said a thing.
Take her and get her changed. I'm going to see Brigham.
Hey, last time I was trapped with him, he tried to eat me! Hey, come back! Oh, great. You, me and your appetite.
Consider yourself lucky, Charley. I've just eaten. Literally.
I don't understand.
We are demons. We demons like a bit of nice meat now and again, but to be honest, we thrive on raw emotion. Fear, hate, jealousy and anger, best meal of the day.
You should have a big wooden spoon for stirring things up.
I should get dressed if I were you.
And if I don't?
I've still got room for dessert.
Ah. I'll just get dressed, then.
(singing) Dashwood for the White House let the anthem ring, Dashwood for the White House let the children sing.
Door opens.
Brigham.
Dale, my dear. You look marvellous.
So, this is my reward for years of loyalty. Cast off like an old girdle.
Dale, my darling, what are you talking about?
Dress seventeen. Marchosias told me.

Oh, Marchosias told you. Spending a lot of time with him, are you? He's a demon, Dale, my sweet. A mischievious imp. His landlord is the King of Lies and Deceit, Lucifer himself. Marchosias is becoming more trouble than he's worth. Once he's made his broadcast this afternoon, I think it's time to rid ourselves of him. Here, take this.
What is this?
Holy water, Dale. I keep one with me at all times. You have one for yourself. Sprinkle it on him and poof! He's gone, back to everlasting torment and agony.
Right. And this Queen of Hell routine?
Darling, it's just a charade. A thing to make Lucifer rise finally. It's a Queen for him, not me.
All right. The comatose patients are in the PSI room, ready for transfer. I'd like to go and deal with that. I'm sure the people at the Club can deal with the girls and our Queen of Hell.
Traditional corsets I can deal with, but I'm certainly not used to leather.
Mmm, my favourite colour. Bright red.
Where exactly does Marchosias end and Waldo Pickering begin? I'd hate to think he was watching this as well.
What? Don't you like dirty old men?
No, I mean that underneath his bluster he's a decent human being who'd probably hate to see his body abused so by the likes of you.
A few odd memories aside, there's little of the Senator here. Oh yes, I like the spikes.
Am I supposed to walk in those boots? Those heels'll have someone's, well, eye out if they get down that far.
Spikes are very popular with Lucifer, you know. The denizens of Hell, they like that sort of thing. Don't forget the bracelets.
Are you really from Hell?
And I like your hair up that way.
Don't change the subject.
You seem like an extraordinarily intelligent girl. You tell me.
I don't think you are. I don't know who or what you really are, but all that sulphur and brimstone
The Hellfire Club likes it. Dashwood likes it.
Who's he?
Someone's coming.
Certainly are. I wonder who?
All right, you two. The one in cell five. Be careful, he can be dangerous.
Cell door opened electronically.
Doctor Pargeter. You couldn't have come at a better time. We think we know how to cure me.
Just hold still while they put the cuffs on.
Now I'm quite willing to come along provided you put me back onto the PSI machine. You see
Quiet, Zebadiah. I'm not in the mood.
You see, Gideon? It'll work out. (hauled away) No, no.
Cell door slides shut.
Poor mad fool. Quite delusional.
Turning pages.
Yeah, well, I got your name here but no special entry pass. Who's she?
[OC]: What? Oh, oh yes. This is Miss Kowalczck, my personal assistant. She should be cleared as well. Now hurry up, man. We haven't got all day. Mister Dashwood will be waiting.
He ain't here.
[OC]: Well, Doctor Pargeter, then.
Yeah, okay. You'll need to sign in here, okay?
[OC]: Right-o. On our way.
Beep. Door slides open.

Guard probably can't see us now. He'll be in that small room. The first thing I want to do is check up on that Zebadiah chap in the holding cell area. That's where I brought him back to after those demons attacked us. Can you try and find the Doctor?
BECKY-LEE: Down here?
Yes, I think so. Wait for me.
Mister Lethbridge Stewart? How nice of you to come by.
Door slides open.
Hello, more visitors. Can't have finished with the poor delusional Zebadiah already. BECKY-LEE: Afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Anyone here gone mad and works for
something called UNIT?
Someone laughs.
BECKY-LEE: Not you, evidently.
Over here, young lady. Did you say UNIT?
BECKY-LEE: That's right. Do you know Lethbridge Stewart?
The Brigadier! I certainly used to. Well, I'm the Doctor, and
BECKY-LEE: Doctor? Charley's Doctor?
Charley? Yes. Do you know where she is?
BECKY-LEE: She's safe, back at my house with my grandfather.
Excellent. Couldn't be in safer hands, then. Er, who are you?
BECKY-LEE: Becky-Lee. I'm everyone's get-out clause.
If you could just sign in, Mister Lethbridge Stewart.
Yes, of course.
What about your personal assistant?
Who?
Oh, Miss Kowalczck. She's gone to park our er, she's gone to park our transport. She'll buzz back later.
Let's go. And oh, Joe, quickly, turn your TV sound up, please.
Okay.
Senator Waldo Pickering, one of the candidates for Governorship. Senator Pickering, may I ask you
This won't take long, boys. You see, all I have to announce is this. As of now, I'm standing down as candidate for Governor.
Gasps
Senator, surely you
My reasons for this decision are mighty simple. I no longer believe myself to be the best man for the job.
Well, this is amazing. Senator, Senator Pickering, I was wondering if
Well, what a surprise.
Indeed a surprise. Still, back to the business in hand. I'd really like to see that chap I brought back to you. Zebadiah Doe, I think you called him?
Oh, I'm sorry, but you've wasted your journey. He's heavily under sedation. Now, if there's nothing else.
Well, I was hoping to talk to you about the experiments in general, really.

I've a heavy workload tonight, and of course we all want to watch Mister Dashwood's programme later. Joe, could you see Mister Lethbridge Stewart off the premises. BECKY-LEE: Charley will be fine. She's probably watching cartoons or something. Having a soda with grandpappy. So, let's concentrate on the here and now. She wanted me to find you. So did the Brigadier.
Ah, good old Lethbridge Stewart. I saw him earlier. Didn't recognise me, of course. BECKY-LEE: Do a lot of undercover disguise work, yeah?
Sort of. Man of a million faces, you see.
BECKY-LEE: What do we do now? The Brigadier was nabbed by some woman doctor and
The redoubtable Doctor Pargeter, no doubt.
BECKY-LEE: Whoever. But she didn't see me, so we should be able to get out easily enough, meet up with the Brig and Charley and
No, no. While I was free to move around earlier, I examined that laboratory of Doctor Pargeter's. The doors from these cells can be operated from within there as an additional security measure.
BECKY-LEE: Or a last line of defence.
Well indeed, that too. However, there's no point in me getting free when there are guards everywhere.
BECKY-LEE: But if we could get the building evacuated?

BRIGADIER: Guard probably can't see us now. He'll be in that small room. The first thing I want to do is check up on that Zebadiah chap in the holding cell area. That's where I brought him back to after those demons attacked us. Can you try and find the Doctor?
BRIGADIER: BECKY-LEE: Down here?
BRIGADIER: Yes, I think so. Wait for me.

CRANE: BECKY-LEE: Becky-Lee. I'm everyone's get-out clause.

CRANE: The redoubtable Doctor Pargeter, no doubt.

CHARLEY: Hello, everybody. This is awfully nice of you. Ow! Ow! Sorry. Not used to this er, interesting outfit. Spikes are giving me a bit of a problem.

Sorry, Zebadiah, I have to leave you now.
What? What are you doing?
You have exhibited the most amazing mental capacity this machine has ever recorded. Wasted on you. So we're taking all of you and distributing it amongst these poor wretches.
That's why you needed catatonics. No active brain patterns to wipe first. That's inhuman!
No. That's science. That's technology. This, however, is goodbye.
Door opens.
Bye.
No. No! You're duplicating my brainwaves. Weakening the original. My brain, my mind, my memories. Noooooo!

I remember now. Hello, everyone. I'm the Doctor.
2: No, no, I'm the Doctor.

Hold my bride's body steady, friends, for now, by reversing the Trans-D's field, I inhabit her empty brain with soul of a demon Queen.

Welcome to Earth, my spouse, and. Aw, she's unconcious. No matter. The journey must have been too much for the weak Earthly shell she now inhabits. Never fear. Let her be carried to my private chambers where she can awaken at her leisure, and the union can be consummated.
Cheers.

Next door, in his beloved Hellfire Club ballroom. With his new bride, I gather.

The Good Book tells us that King David, when he was grown old, took unto himself a young maiden to be his comforter, and her name was Bildad the Shuhite.
No, that was one of Job's comforters.
Can you be so hard as to deny me the same

Lethbridge Stewart.

A friend.

Your theology is no better than your security, really, is it.
You can know squat all about the Bible like myself and still gross eight point three five million dollars in the last fiscal year.
And with that you create your own state, your own short step to the White House.
That's about it, yes.
And your infernal PSI machine?
Ah, the coup de gr@ce. I'll soon use that to extract their minds then replace them with Lucifer's demons so I have an army to do my dirty work.
While all the poor people's minds are trapped onto a quantum CD thing ready for you to tap into whenever you need to.
Shame to let all that experience go to waste.

Why, thank you. I

And who am I?

My sweet, beautiful girlie, no one ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the public. When I start my sermon, that poor collection of rubes, subnormals, hypocrites and white trailer trash is going to to plumb crazy.

And then, when I cry out Vote for the Good Lord, Vote for Dashwood, the world will witness the biggest, most powerful puissance. Well, a certain evening in Nuremburg springs to mind.

Your friend Scott, anxious to talk to you, perhaps? He seems to be trying to get your attention from a little booth up there.

Zebadiah's right, Alistair. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a car outside. I think I'll go, well, somewhere they won't find me very quickly.
But

Quick, get us away from here. You!

Just up and vamoosed from my head, Dashwood. It's just me here now. BECKY-LEE: Oh, and we found this in the Hellfire Club. No one seems to know what it is.

BECKY-LEE: Hiya, Charley girl. Where's the Doctor?
Walking on gravel.
Hello. Don't think we've met.
BECKY-LEE: You're the Doctor? Who was the other guy, Brigadier?

BECKY-LEE: You really are one marshmallow short of a Count Chocula, aren't you.

BECKY-LEE: From Marchosias, perhaps.

BECKY-LEE: The demon who took over grandpoppy's body.

No
Idea.

Crash, smash.

Er, well

Ah. Sorry.
What were you doing with this machine?
Well, I, that is

Put my consciousness into a demon's body. Set me up alongside Lucifer himself, as one of his strategists.
Using this PSI machine and our friend here. Sorry, didn't catch the name.
Er, Crane. Gideon Crane.

No?
No.

That's right.
What?
I get about.

Spoilsport, Doctor.

Not at all, Charley. Marchosias has just adopted that name and form because it suits him. It's what Dashwood wanted to see most, to influence his Hellfire Club. You missed out the important bit.
Oh yes, that's right. Their diet. They feed on the negative neuronic emissions of sentient beings. Pain, fear, anxiety, jealousy. A psionivore battens on it like maggots on rotting fruit.
So they use people's bad thoughts and desires?
And this Hellfire Club was perfect. A ridiculous charade which brought people together in one place with enough negative energy to draw the psionivores into becoming a gestalt entity.
That'll be me, then.
The Hellfire Club has contacted Lucifer and his demons for centuries. My ancestor, Sir Francis Dashwood, was

A cultured, amiable scholarly man. His so-called Club was simply a group of chums who spent weekends with him at Medmenham from time to time. No doubt they drank more than was good for them, but the nearest thing they had to a manifestation of the devil was one of their inebriated number sticking horns on his head and jumping out of a bush yelling boo. Certainly Sir Francis was interested in reinventing the ancient Greek Eleusinian mysteries, but that's a far cry from human sacrifices and pacts with anyone called Lucifer.
You lie.

Dashwood, the Hellfire Sir Francis was a fictitious caricature of the real man, dreamt up by his political enemies, reinforced by centuries of sensational writers who never bothered to check their facts.

The PSI machine.

Dashwood and Marchosias.

You seem upset.

Oh, I'm going to help the police with their enquiries. I'll see you later, perhaps?
You're a brave man, Mister Crane.
I had a brave mind inside me for a while, Doctor, that's all. Right now I'ma gibbering wreck inside. Er, see you later, old man.

Yes. Why?
I'll catch you up, yes?
All right. Goodbye, Brigadier.
Oh yes. Goodbye, Miss Pollard.
Goodbye.
A kiss on the cheek.
Oh.
Footsteps on gravel.
Well, Brigadier, here we are again.

Yes, indeed. Every time I think I've seen the last of you, up you pop again. I like the new face, by the way. See if you can't hold on to it a little longer than some of your predecessors, there's a good chap.
It's always a pleasure teaming up with you. Someone dependable, solid as a rock.

You too, Doctor. You too. Now, run along. Disappear into the ether, or the Sheriff will be wanting to question us both about your involvement, and that could keep us both in this country far longer than is healthy for either of us.
I'll see you around, then, as they say in these parts.
I'm sure of it, Doctor. Goodbye.
Goodbye, Alistair.
Footsteps on gravel.
(at a distance) It was fun!
Fun? (chuckles) Odd idea of fun you have, Doctor.
Off we go then, Charley.
He seemed awfully nice, your friend the Brigadier. One of the best, you might Say.
Oh no, Charley. The best. Where to now?
Console controls adjusted. The Tardis dematerialises.
Er, Doctor? When the psionivores had me in their Hell place, they said I was useless to them.
That wasn't very nice.
It was odd. I wasn't entirely sure of what I was hearing, being a bit giddy and all that. But I'm sure one of them said I was useless to them because I was dead.
Yes, people say the strangest things, Charley. Psionivores in particular. Now, how about a quick spin round the Crucis Nebula? It's very pretty. Colours you'll never have dreamt of. Stars, gas clouds
An evil monster set on universal destruction, no doubt.
Oh, Charley, it's a beautiful universe out there. Let's just go somewhere nice and
quiet and peaceful, and do a bit of star-gazing.
Oh, yes.
We can leave saving the universe from monsters for another day, all right?
